settings.specialized__what_title: What is Anemia and Hair Loss
settings.specialized__what_content:
Anemia is a condition that occurs when the body does not have sufficient healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen to the body's organs. This most often occurs when the body does not have enough iron, and this is known as iron-deficiency Anemia.

Red blood cells contain hemoglobin which is an iron-rich protein that allows red blood cells to carry oxygen from your lungs to the rest of your body. When your body does not have enough iron, red blood cells cannot effectively perform their functions.

The primary job of red blood cells is to carry oxygen (hemoglobin) from the lungs to the body and to carry carbon dioxide away from the body and back to the lungs to be expelled as waste. When the body does not have enough functioning red blood cells to perform this vital action, a person will begin to experience a number of symptoms.

There are a few different types of Anemia and every type of Anemia causes red blood cell levels to drop. Here are a few reasons red blood cell levels may become low:

- Your hemoglobin does not function properly
- Your body cannot make enough red blood cells
- Your body cannot produce enough hemoglobin, resulting in low hemoglobin

settings.heading: Symptoms of Iron-Deficiency Anemia
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• Tiredness
  • Shortness of breath
  • Weakness
  • Paleness
  • Dizziness
  • Abnormal cravings
  • Dry skin
  • Damaged or dry hair
  • Hair loss

settings.heading: How common is Iron-Deficiency Anemia?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Iron deficiency is a global issue that is noted as affecting nearly 20-25% of the population. Nearly three million Americans have Iron Deficiency Anemia which makes it the most common blood condition in the USA.

settings.heading: What are the best sources of iron?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
There are a number of sources of iron. While iron is known to come from meat,  there are also a number of vegetarian and vegan friendly options that are iron rich! These include:

  • Spinach
  • Kale
  • Beans and Lentils
  • Cashews
  • Tofu
  • Seeds such as chia seeds, hemp seeds, and pumpkin seeds

settings.heading: Is iron deficiency and Anemia the same?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Anemia occurs when the body has a lack of hemoglobin and this is most commonly caused by iron-deficiency. Iron deficiency though is a lack of iron in the body. While these are commonly linked conditions, iron deficiency can exist without Anemia.

settings.heading: Can Iron-Deficiency Anemia become serious?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Yes. If Anemia goes untreated for a long period of time it can have serious health complications. It can put a strain on vital organs such as the heart, as the heart will attempt to work harder to get oxygen to the other organs. This can cause Left Ventricular Hypertrophy, a heart condition that is the result of thickening walls of the heart muscle.

settings.heading: What causes Iron-Deficiency Anemia?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Iron deficiency can be caused by a number of things which include:

  • Not having an iron-rich diet
  • Chronic blood loss
  • Losing a large amount of blood quickly
  • Surgery
  • Peptic ulcers
  • Colon Polyps
  • Needing more iron in your diet because of pregnancy or an illness

It is important to write down the symptoms you are experiencing and bring them to your doctor. They may want to send you for additional tests to see the possible cause of your Anemia.

settings.heading: How is Iron-Deficiency Anemia treated?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
If you feel you may be iron deficient then it's important that you visit your doctor and have your levels tested. Depending on the severity of your iron deficiency, they may recommend iron vitamins, prescription iron tablets, intravenous fluids, oxygen, pain relievers, or even blood transfusions.

It can take several months to reach optimal iron levels so it is important to work with your doctor and be tested regularly to ensure you are getting enough iron.

settings.heading: What are some of the other types of Anemia which are not cause by iron-deficiency?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• Aplastic Anemia
  • Diamond-Blackfan Anemia
  • Fanconi Anemia
  • Hemolytic Anemia
  • Pernicious Anemia
  • Sickle cell Anemia

settings.heading: Is hair loss from Iron-Deficiency Anemia permanent?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: If your hair loss is due to low iron levels then your hair should grow back and resume its normal growth cycle once your Iron-Deficiency Anemia has been treated.

settings.heading: Are there any other options to help support hair re-growth?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
While hair loss caused by Anemia should resume to its normal rate once the iron deficiency has been treated, there are a number of best practices related to hair care that you can implement to support your hair and hair regrowth journey. They include:

Best hair care practices:

  • Use gentle hair care and avoid harsh ingredients such as parabens, phthalates, sulfates, and artificial fragrances.
  • Support your hair health and growth with Tru Bloom Vitamins. Our Tru Bloom Hair Vitamins have received thousands of positive reviews from real customers, many of whom have shared their hair and health journeys with us. Visit our 60-Day Challenge to see thousands of reviews and before/after photos.
  • Swap your cotton pillowcase for a satin one instead. Cotton can pull at your hair as you sleep, causing more breakage and damage to your hair. A satin pillowcase will allow your hair to move more freely and without damage. Side note: Satin pillowcases, unlike silk pillowcases, are a great vegan option.
  • Apply scalp treatments weekly. The Beach Goddess Hot Oil Hair Mask is a natural hair treatment to help deeply nourish your scalp and hair to support your best hair growth. This incredible Hot Oil Hair Mask contains proven Hair Superfoods, which can fully penetrate the human hair shaft - to repair & revitalize hair from the inside-out.
  • Reduce heat styling practices. Instead of using heat tools on your hair try to embrace your natural hair texture or use heatless hair styling methods. Heat tools can cause damage to your hair and may result in hair breakage.
